description: Immanuel Kant's critical philosophy establishing the limits and structure of human knowledge through transcendental idealism
author: Bryan A. Spruk

entries.definition: Objects conform to our cognition, not the other way around. The mind actively structures experience rather than passively receiving it.
examples: Space and time as forms of intuition that organize sensory data

entries.definition: We can only know things as they appear to us (phenomena), never as they are in themselves (noumena). The 'thing-in-itself' remains forever beyond human cognition.
examples: We know the apple as red and round, but not its essential nature

entries.definition: Space and time are a priori forms of intuition that structure all experience. They are necessary conditions for any possible experience.
examples: Geometry as the science of space
Arithmetic as the science of time

entries.definition: Innate concepts (causality, substance, unity, plurality, reality, negation, limitation, totality) applied to sensory data to make coherent experience possible.
examples: Causality: every event has a cause

entries.definition: Knowledge that is both informative (synthetic) and independent of experience (a priori), such as mathematics and basic laws of science.

transcendental_deduction.description: Demonstrate how categories make experience possible

phenomenal_analysis.description: Analyze experience within bounds of possible knowledge
